speaker: akayla brown
utterance: And I think they'd be like, oh, we can just beat the little kids and this and that. They just think that they can just get in our Kool-Aid when they don't even know the flavor.

speaker: aquasia baker
utterance: Ooh! That's a good one, [INAUDIBLE]

speaker: ira glass
utterance: That same day, in Newark, New Jersey, a stranger on the train that carries you between terminals at Newark Airport got into the Kool-Aid of a man named James Braly, asking where he was headed.

speaker: james braly
utterance: I am on my way to meet my brother-- or my half-brother, depending on how you look at it. The internet is a very, very strange thing.

speaker: man
utterance: Oh, really?

speaker: james braly
utterance: Yes.

speaker: man
utterance: First day?

speaker: james braly
utterance: For the first time.

speaker: man
utterance: Seriously?

speaker: james braly
utterance: I'm absolutely serious.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The half-brother, Jan, who is from Norway, recently learned the name of his father for the very first time, did an internet search, discovered James' family in the United States, and was coming to meet them. The guy on the train asked James, what proof do you have? You going to get a DNA test or something?

speaker: james braly
utterance: Uh, not unless he asks me for a lot of money.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: When James gets to terminal A, he scans the crowd and spots him.

speaker: james braly
utterance: I think that's him.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: His half-brother's a 52-year-old man with a waxed handlebar mustache, hair thinned from chemo, and his dad's eyes. He is instantly recognizable, James says, as family.

speaker: james braly
utterance: Can I get you a drink?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Welcome to WBEZ Chicago. It's This American Life, distributed by Public Radio International. Coming up all this hour, stories of all kinds, from all over, all from the past seven days. Stay with us.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This past Saturday, the first of the seven days that we're covering in today's show, I Skyped with Hyder Akbar-- he's in Kabul, Afghanistan-- to find out if anything was happening there that might be interesting for the radio. Hyder's been on our show a few times. He grew up in California, but his family is from Afghanistan. After college, Hyder moved there.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: He said that one of the guys that he's close to, Josef, was thinking about traveling to Kunar Province. That's where he's from. This is an area that's been a Taliban stronghold in the past. It's on the border with Pakistan.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: If the Afghan government were to lose control of the country to the Taliban, it would probably start in Kunar. And that's a real possibility-- civil war, the government falling. So what's happening in Kunar right now tells us whether that is in the cards in the future.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Let me grab Josef, who's here, who actually was trying to get my dad to let him go back home tomorrow. I can bring him in here and talk to him about what's going on.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: That seems great. Yeah, bring him in.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: What are you doing when you [INAUDIBLE]? OK, just a second. Let me--

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So Josef shows up.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And Hyder asks him what's happening in Kunar right now.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Oh. Oh. He says the most interesting thing is that the Americans have just pulled out of an area called Pashangar, in his area, where there was almost like a local militia with them and then the Americans controlling them. And they pulled out of that base. And now the problems have started.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And they're warning everybody, they're telling everybody, look, the Americans are leaving. The Americans are out. We're coming for you guys. We're going to go after whoever cooperated with the Afghan government, with the Americans. You guys better be careful. And they've started attacking the Afghan National Army. That, he says, is the main thing going on right now.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Wow.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: There might be a chance to get interesting audio there, too, that this might be of interest. So let's see. Let's see.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So they went to see, in an ancient Toyota Corolla. They drove up there. They'd have to be careful, stay under the radar. A few days before, Hyder said, a few guys with the Afghan National Army were stopped on the road coming from Kunar and killed.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: They left on Tuesday. They were going to be back Tuesday night or Wednesday morning. Our plan was to talk again 6 o'clock Wednesday night, Kabul time.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Then, Wednesday, Hyder wasn't answering any emails or any phone calls. 6 o'clock came and went. I started to get worried. And then, after an hour or so, I saw that he was online, on Skype. So I tried him.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Hello?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Hyder?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Hey, Ira.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So it's Wednesday, and you just got back from Kunar Province.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Yes, I did. I just got back from Kunar. This was probably the most intense experience of my life a few hours ago. So that's kind of at the forefront of my mind.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: What happened?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: I was coming back with a story. And I was very excited, driving down, taking in the view of Kunar, which is actually very scenic. So I had my headphones on. And I'm driving down.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And I have Josef, who lives with me now and works with me. And Sartor, who you've been introduced to through the previous documentaries, was sitting in the back. And I wanted to drive myself.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And we were coming by this bend in the road where it slows down a little bit. And we were passing by that bend when, all of a sudden, somebody jumped up behind this wall. He jumped up behind the wall, and he tried stopped the car. He put his hand on the car twice, like-- [BANGING] --and yelled, stop.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And I had my headphones on, so I just looked through the corner of my eye. And I see confusion. And I see Josef next to me, yelling, go go, go! And I looked at him, and he had his AK-47 pointed straight at us.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: When he had his AK-47 pointed straight at us and I saw that, I just floored the accelerator. I floored the accelerator, and I was like, oh, not time to stop. And my music was still going on in my ears.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And then, all of a sudden, I just see firing. And they had a few men on that side of the road firing at our car, and then a few men on the other side of the road, as well, too, firing at our car. They're just emptying into our car.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Josef is ducked down. Sartor is ducked down in the back. I had my head up, because I have to look at the road. Here, the tires go flat. They hit both tires. And as they hit both tires, I'm kind of looking up and trying to still make it. We're probably going a few hundred meters past them now.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And then, all of a sudden, I see another person jump out. And he had an RPG in his hand. And he's looking right at me, and I'm looking right at him. And he shot the RPG right at me. He shot the RPG at me.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And I'm seeing this rocket come towards me, and I'm like, OK, it's fine. I've done enough here. I had a pretty fun life. Obviously, all of that went through my mind. I was like, OK, it's done. It's done. I'm done.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And the RPG-- this is why everybody was so shocked. So at that second, we hit like a little bump on the road. And the RPG goes straight through the engine of my car, instead of coming directly at me. So it hits the engine right in front of me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And is the car on fire? Are you in danger of the car blowing up?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: [INAUDIBLE] the engine on fire at this point. [INAUDIBLE] being able to take a picture later on. I could probably email this to you later on. But I'm going to show you on webcam real quick. You might be able to get a sense of how damaged it was and--

speaker: ira glass
utterance: OK. All right, you're holding this up to the webcam. We're talking over Skype.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Yeah. Can you see the car?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Oh my god. So the whole front is dented in. And then is the windshield busted in? It's hard to see.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Everything's busted in. The whole car went on fire. Do you see that hole right there?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Yeah. So there's a huge hole in the driver's side in the front, on the hood.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: [INAUDIBLE] right now. Yeah, that's where the RPG went through. And you're looking at it in reverse right now, I think, because of the cam. But that's basically where I was sitting, right above it.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And that's where the RPG came through. And that's where I missed the bump of the RPG. I mean, he was aiming straight at me. Like I said, when I saw that RPG come at me, I thought it was done. So--

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So the car is on fire. You guys are in the car. These guys are shooting just a couple of hundred meters behind you. And maybe have they stopped at that point?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: So at this point, it's quiet for a second. We're all kind of looking around. Right then, these two pickup trucks of ANA soldiers are driving by on the opposite side, going in their direction.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This is the Afghan army. This is friendly to you--

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: The Afghan National Army, yeah. So we see the Afghan National Army, two pickup trucks, plenty of guys in there. So we're like, OK-- phew-- coast clear. The ANA's going to be able to take care of this. And we get kind of relieved for a second.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: We get out of the car, we just see the ANA drive off. They saw it. They saw our car on fire. They definitely heard the RPG his us, because that doesn't make low noise.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: They heard the gunfire. And they just drive off. They just drive off, and I'm like, OK. All right.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: They drive off in the direction of the guys who are shooting at you, or just in some other direction?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: No, past them. Past them. Past them. They were driving in that direction, and they kept driving. So at this point, Josef just runs off. Josef has run off. He's a good hundred meters away from us at this point.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And me and Sartor are kind of just looking at the car on fire, and we're like, what the hell? And we're looking at it, and Josef's screaming, get the hell out of here! Get the hell out of here!

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And I just looked at Sartor, and I was like, dude, my laptop bag's in there. Everything's in there. So we both run in. We open the door to go inside to grab the laptop bag out of it, with my laptop and other stuff in there.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And so as we do that, they start firing again. Luckily, the car covered us. And the bullets just hit the back of the car as we were on the side of the car trying to get the laptop bag out. We managed to get the laptop bag out. And then I'm kind of hiding behind the car.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: I take out my iPhone, because I'm like, OK, I've got to record this a little bit, at least, for you guys. I was like, I want to record this thing. This is an interesting thing. I look at my iPhone. It has, like, 1% battery, 2%. I'm like, [BLEEP].

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: So I have this on record, and I see Josef just come running back down. And it was kind of funny. He's like, what are you doing? I'm like, I need to record the car, I need to record the car for the thing. Remember, we came here to do the radio thing.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And he cursed you guys out and punched the hood. And basically, he said, F This American Life. What the hell are you going to do with This American Life when you're dead? And he started dragging me away.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And right then, the phone turned off too. The phone turned off too, so it didn't save the recording, either. And he's dragging me away. As he's dragging me away--

speaker: ira glass
utterance: OK, soon after this in the conversation, I let Hyder know that if he is ever again in any situation where he might get killed, it is OK if he runs away and stops recording for the radio show. So he explained that they went around the bend. They saw two civilian cars stopped there. They were still being shot at. So they got into those cars. They got away.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This was the first time, Hyder said, that somebody specifically tried to kill him. And he thinks that they wanted him because they were letting other cars pass by on the road, and they specifically tried to stop his car. But who was it who was targeting him? And why were they targeting him? That wasn't clear to him at all.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: That's something I'm going to have to think about and figure out tonight, in the next couple of days.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Well, what are the possibilities? List through right now, tick off a couple of possibilities, just so I understand. What could it be?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: It could have been the Taliban. It could have been the Taliban, who might have been following me a lot more closely than I realized, following my locations, where I'm spending the night, where I'm living. They definitely knew exactly where I was. I can't think of anything personal, in terms of any personal feuds, et cetera. So it'd be most likely the Taliban or people in Kunal that are with the insurgency that don't see me, I guess, as a threat.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And Hyder, is it as simple as you and your dad aren't necessarily so crazy about the current government in Afghanistan, but they know you definitely do not like the Taliban? And is it as simple as that?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Almost as simple as that. The one thing I would add onto that is they could see us as being even more of a threat because we're not that close to this government anymore, because we don't approve of many things that are going on in the government. They can sideline a lot of other people very easily by saying, oh, these guys are corrupted individuals, involved with the government, fattening their pockets. But when they see me driving around in a [BLEEP] Corolla and just talking to people, engaging them, and being pretty sincere in my efforts, that's seen as much more of a threat, because they could delegitimize the Afghan government and the officials involved with them much easier.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And it's not crazy to think that Hyder is now at a point where he would be worth killing. His family's from Kunar. His father and uncle were in the insurgency in Kunar that drove out the Soviets in the 1980s. When the current Afghan government came to power after September 11, Hyder's dad was appointed governor of Kunar. They have friends there. They have a base of support.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And as the Americans pull out in the next two years, there's going to be a power vacuum in the country. And people are getting in position for that, including Hyder. He is setting himself up to do politics. The way that he explains it, he says he wants to be the Afghan equivalent of a congressman, though with a militia. You need a militia, because it's Afghanistan.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: We talked for a while. Hyder insisted that he is planning on going back to Kunar soon. And he's going to do it just like he did this time, in another beat-up old car, to prove that they didn't scare him, to prove that he wasn't going to stay away, which I really hope that his mom and his dad and his uncle talk him out of. And then we finally got to the reason for his trip in the first place, the story that he was so excited to bring back, that he ended up risking his life for, of what was happening in the province.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So just review the highlights for me. So let's talk about what you saw when you were there. What's interesting?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: OK, so we drove up there. We drove up there yesterday. And we went into the Pesh Valley.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: It's actually kind of funny. So the Pesh Valley's sort of like the valley of death. It was the place that was considered very dangerous. And some interesting new dynamics have emerged there with the ANA, the Afghan National Army.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Again, this is the government's army. This for the government of Afghanistan.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: The ANA, the Afghan National Army, is in control there now. The Americans have pulled out. What's going on because of that is that a lot of people, especially the civilian population, is siding with the ANA now. The ANA is just culturally much more aware. They've been able to make inroads amongst the population.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: They've been able to push the Taliban out, especially from the main roads. I was driving by areas where people used to get stopped and beheaded, government officials or those considered working with the Americans, driving past all of these potholes in the road where they had laid down IEDs. And that was fine. It was fine. And we're all taking in the scenery.

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: And it was a very heartwarming story, actually. I was actually very excited to come back. I was kind of aware, I was like, OK, maybe good news is not always that fun to report about. I was like, but it'll be exciting to finally come back. And I was very hopeful and feeling pretty jolly.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Because it was so hopeful that the Afghan National Army was doing a decent job?

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: Exactly. Exactly, that there's hope for this country, there's hope for security in this country, there's hope for stability in this country. And as somebody who has spent the last 10 years involved in this place, that was incredible news for me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Hyder Akbar. He's the author of the book Come Back to Afghanistan. This song that's playing right now is one that he swears was playing on his iPod when he was ambushed. And it's such a weird choice that it's hard to believe that he'd make that up. It's the Geto Boys' 1991 hit, "Mind Playing Tricks On Me."

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Well, if you live in a part of the country that has already had snow this year, you may find it hard to relate to the thrill experienced by some people in Arizona this past week. Lisa Pollak explains.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: When I heard that an outdoor mall in Tuscon was promising snow on Saturday, a day when the high temperature hit 77 degrees, I figured there were only two possible explanations-- a pre-Christmas meteorological miracle or a ski resort style snow machine. But there was, in fact, a third option. I heard about it from Melanie Sutton, the senior marketing manager at La Encantada mall, the mall that sponsors the annual event known as the Enchanted Snowfall. She said that what we were about to see falling from sky that night was a desert style snow.

speaker: melanie sutton
utterance: As our tagline, we say, "98% magic, 2% soap."

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: Oh, wow. So it literally is, like, that's the ingredient, is soap? I mean, besides the magic.

speaker: melanie sutton
utterance: Correct. The ingredient is soap. But they're shaped as snowflakes.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: Got that? Me, neither. But minutes later, along with hundreds of parents and kids in the mall's open-air courtyard, I had a chance to see it for myself.

speaker: dad 1
utterance: Oh, oh, here we go.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: "Oh, oh, here we go," I heard one of the dads say. Then there was a whooshing sound, followed by white stuff falling from the sky.

speaker: child 1
utterance: It's snowing!

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: From a distance, I can report that it did indeed resemble snow-- heavy, white flakes lit up by spotlights in the darkness. Up close, though, it was hard to be fooled. Imagine little clumps of bath suds or globs of latte foam, with a faintly fresh smell.

speaker: dad 2
utterance: There it is, look!

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: This man is talking to his three-year-old son, Cameron, who at first seemed to be saying how much he liked the snow--

speaker: cameron
utterance: I don't like snow.

speaker: dad 2
utterance: You like snow.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: --but on closer examination, was actually saying how much he didn't like the snow.

speaker: cameron
utterance: Don't like snow.

speaker: dad 2
utterance: It's OK.

speaker: cameron
utterance: I don't like snow.

speaker: dad 2
utterance: It's OK.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: Cameron was the exception. All around me, kids seemed to be going insane with joy. Over by the Apple store, a group of them had planted themselves under one of the faux snow machines and seemed to be trying to get as much white foam on their hair and clothes as possible. Others ran around with outstretched hands, trying to catch enough to make mushy snowballs and smash it on each other's heads.

speaker: child 2
utterance: My hair!

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: One boy walked up to me with a mass of suds in each hand and a look on his face like he couldn't believe his good fortune.

speaker: boy 1
utterance: Look at how much snow I have.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: Suddenly I felt a sense of duty. Shouldn't these kids know the truth? I would break it to them gently.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: It looks kind of like soap.

speaker: boy 1
utterance: That's because it is soap. It's kind of like regular snow. But if it gets in your eyes, your eyes just terribly burn. It's just bubbles, but I can't believe it! I've never seen this happen before!

speaker: child 3
utterance: So fun! And it's soap!

speaker: boy 2
utterance: I tasted it. It tastes like soap.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: About halfway through the show, I noticed I was starting to cough. And I wasn't the only one. I overheard this lady talking to her husband. Everyone's coughing, she said.

speaker: man 4
utterance: We're all going to get cancer.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: What did you say?

speaker: man 4
utterance: We're all going to get cancer.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: Why did you say-- [COUGHS]

speaker: man 4
utterance: Just listen. Everybody's standing here coughing, right? So it can't be good for you.

speaker: man 4
utterance: Yeah. Right? There you go. There you go. Get you some.

speaker: lisa pollak
utterance: I checked with Melanie, the mall's marketing manager. She assured me that whatever was in the bubbles had been tested and was nontoxic. Though I believed her, I was a little relieved when the Enchanted Snowfall powered down after 15 minutes. Like a lot of things about the holidays, it was at its best from a distance, and a little went a long way.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Lisa Pollak. Coming up, a guy walks into a bar-- usually not a life-or-death situation. That's in a minute from Chicago Public Radio and Public Radio International when our program continues.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. This week, instead of the usual sort of theme we do on our show, our theme is just the seven days that have just passed. We have stories, small and personal, and big and national, and international.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Monday, you probably heard, House Speaker John Boehner issued his counterproposal to avoid the fiscal cliff. It was promptly rejected by the White House. By Wednesday, there were front-page stories that Republican leaders are considering a fallback plan to extend tax cuts to the middle class now, fight about the rest of it in January or February.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Also this week, Boehner cracked the whip in his own party. Republicans who didn't vote his way lost committee assignments. He warned to other House members that he would be watching. To put all of this in perspective, I called veteran Congress-watcher Norman Ornstein, who happened to be in Prague when I phoned him. His official title is Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: But all I care about is that you mention the book--

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And the title of the book is?

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: --which is, It's Even Worse Than It Looks-- How the American Constitutional System Collided with the New Politics of Extremism.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Consider it mentioned.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So you're in Prague this week. Isn't this kind of a big week not to be near Capitol Hill for somebody like you?

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: It's a good week to be away from Capitol Hill in a lot of ways.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: How so?

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: Well, it seems like a big week. But the fact is we're in the middle of an end game. And I've been kind of bemused by all of the focus on the every-minute maneuvering of Speaker John Boehner and President Obama, including a heavy focus on the fact that Boehner didn't pose for a picture with the President at the White House Christmas party.

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: And there's one important principle to keep in mind. When does an end game end? At the end. And the end is not this week.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Are you basically saying that this is a week we might as well ignore the news from Capitol Hill?

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: Yes. I'm saying that there are naturally going to be people who follow every little twist and turn. But it doesn't really matter.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So this is the thing that I was wondering, is, when you look at this maneuvering, can you tell how it's going to play out?

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: The answer is two-fold. The first part is, no, you can't tell how it's going to play out. But all of these ploys and, in some ways, histrionics are par for the course. So taking the temperature on any one of them doesn't really tell us that much.

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: Now, what I would have to say, though, is the second point. And it's frankly a giant caveat here. We are going through the most dysfunctional politics I've seen in 43 years. So I think there's a pretty good chance we'll get a patchwork deal to get us past this dilemma before the end of the year.

speaker: norman ornstein
utterance: But I also think that there's a substantial chance, much higher than it would have been if we were looking at the process 20 years ago or 10 years ago, even 5 years ago, that we'll slip over into January. And it might take a jolt, a serious jolt, from the markets to bring us to some kind of conclusion here.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Norman Ornstein. I asked him, why do they even bother going through the theater this week? Why not just skip to the part where they actually hammer out the deal? His answer, I thought, was interesting.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: He said that the Republicans need to demonstrate to Grover Norquist and Rush Limbaugh and all their own constituents that they tried everything, their back is against the wall, there was no other choice before they can raise taxes. The Democrats have their own version of it. They have to demonstrate to their base they had no choice but to cut entitlements before any deal. Both sides need to say no, he says, for a while.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Wednesday night, New Orleans, French Quarter. A 25-year-old blonde girl named Joni Cooper is going up to everybody in this bar, asking a question that you probably wouldn't expect to hear on a night out drinking.

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: Hey, guys.

speaker: bar patron 1
utterance: How are you?

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: Can I come chat with you?

speaker: bar patron 1
utterance: Sure.

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: Well, my name's Joni. And I'm here with NO/AIDS. We're doing free HIV testing today. Would y'all maybe be interested in getting tested tonight?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: NO/AIDS is an organization in Louisiana that works to prevent and reduce the spread of HIV and help treat people who are infected. Louisiana has the fourth highest estimated AIDS rate in the country. In 2011, nearly 60% of new HIV diagnoses in Louisiana were gay man. 74% were African Americans. So NO/AIDS tries to make finding at your HIV status as convenient as they possibly can, which means, for them, going into bars, asking people to put down their drink for 15 minutes, and come get tested. They get the results on the spot.

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: It's my birthday, so--

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: [SCREAMS]. Happy birthday!

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Joni is pitching a group of guys who are out for their friend's 30th birthday. You might think this would not be a receptive crowd, but listen to what happens.

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: You're doing it right now? Like, what time?

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: We're doing it right now.

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: Let's do it.

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: You want to go?

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: Let's go.

speaker: joni cooper
utterance: All right!

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: Let's go. I'm going to get tested. You coming?

speaker: bar patron 3
utterance: Where?

speaker: bar patron 2
utterance: Right here, right now.

speaker: robin pearce
utterance: You catch someone by surprise. You kind of catch someone off guard, and they're like, oh, well, I guess it's here. I've never done it.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Robin Pearce runs the testing program, which has testing sites all over New Orleans, not just in bars.

speaker: robin pearce
utterance: The statistic is that 1.2 million people in the United States are living with HIV, and one in five of them don't know they have it. So finding the people who don't know that they have HIV is the point of what we're doing.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The week that we're covering here today happened to begin with World AIDS Day. And thinking about that, we sent out a writer, Nathaniel Rich, to watch the HIV testing at one of the highest risk venues NO/AIDS tests at-- Club New Orleans, a five-story sex club for men in the center of the French Quarter, which means that this story might not be appropriate for all children or maybe any of them. It acknowledges the existence of sex. Here's Nathaniel. We changed the name of the guy he's writing about in this story.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Room 300 was the largest bedroom in the club, just large enough to fit a chair and a queen size bed covered with red satin sheets. Sitting cross-legged on the bed was Alex Lee, a 25-year-old counselor for NO/AIDS, who's also a student at the University of New Orleans. He's majoring in anthropology. In fact, he had a final exam the next morning.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: When Mark entered the room, Alex was reading an essay about Occam's razor. Alex asked Mark to sit in the chair. He explained that the HIV test would only detect an infection that occurred more than three months ago. He showed Mark how to use an applicator to swab this mouth-- first his upper gums, then his lower gums. When Mark was finished, he dipped the end of the applicator into a small vial.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Alex set a timer to 20 minutes, the time it takes for a test result to appear, and placed it on the bedside table between them. He asked Mark a series of questions. "When was your last test?" "About a year ago," said Mark, "at a bar, in fact."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: "In the past 12 months," asked Alex, "have you had anal sex with a man?" "Yes," said Mark. "Have you had sex without using a condom?" "As a giver," said Mark. "How about sex with an anonymous, casual, or internet partner, someone you didn't know too well?" "I'm sure I have," said Mark.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: He seemed to become increasingly anxious. He crossed his arms, holding his elbows, hugging his chest. "Have you knowingly had sex with someone who's living with HIV?" "No." "Have you injected any drugs?" "No."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: "Have you had sex with someone who injects drugs?" Mark paused for two seconds. "No," he said. Alex started the next question, but Mark interrupted him. "Yes," he said, "yes, I have." "Sex with someone who injects drugs?" "Yeah. I just didn't know it until after."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: The timer beeped. "Does that mean it's ready?" asked Mark. "No," said Alex. "It just beeps sometimes."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: "It's so funny," said Mark, "and this is so crude, but I did have intercourse last night, not wearing a condom. It's just weird. The guy told me he was negative, but for some reason, after all was said and done, I thought he was really positive. And then I was thinking on the walk home how stupid that was."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Mark had been busy all day at work, so it had been easy to avoid thinking about it. But that evening, he went for a walk and soon found himself standing in front of the club. It was odd, Mark said, because he hadn't visited the club for a year. As soon as he stepped inside, a voice came on the loudspeaker announcing that there would be free HIV testing that evening. Suddenly, Mark understood why he had come to the club, and he felt scared.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: There were five minutes left on the timer. "I'm really anxious," said Mark. He looked it. He was jittery. He rose from his chair. He said he was going to walk around and come back when his result was ready.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: But five minutes later, when the timer went off, Mark was gone. Alex waited another 10 minutes, then another 10. A different man was tested, waited for his result, then left. Still no sign of Mark.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Alex was mystified. In his two years testing men at bars, nobody had ever fled before finding out his results. It was now almost 11:30. His shift had official ended half an hour ago, and his anthropology final was at 10:00 AM.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: As Alex gathered his testing materials, his colleague, Brandon, decided to make one final effort to find Mark. Brandon started in the gym. Mark wasn't there. Nor was Mark in the sauna or the whirlpool.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: He was not in the room called the Bookstore, which doesn't have any books, nor was he in the Barracks. He was not in the so-called Porno Room, in which every surface is made of black rubber. And he was not in the Dungeon.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Brandon paced through the narrow hallways, which are lined with more than 50 tiny bedrooms. Some of the doors were ajar. He saw harnesses and swings. He saw men watching videos.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: And then, in another bedroom, Brandon saw Mark. He was sitting on a bed, talking with a naked man. "Oh," said Mark, "are you looking for me?"

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: Five minutes later, Mark returned to room 300. His fingers were trembling. He was too nervous to sit. Alex told him that his test had come back negative.

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: "Yay!" Mark shouted. He was ecstatic. He asked Alex to show him the result on the test form. "God, I'm so happy. Thank you. Oh my god."

speaker: nathaniel rich
utterance: He thanked Alex a few more times and said he was grateful for the work that NO/AIIDS was doing. Mark even said he wanted to volunteer for the organization, that he felt, as a member of the New Orleans gay community, it was the right thing to do. Then, negative test results in hand, he disappeared into the club.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Nathaniel Rich. He's the author of the forthcoming book Odds Against Tomorrow.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This, what you're listening to right now, is a Samantha Ronson remix, released this week by the Chainsmokers. Except for the Geto Boys, all the songs between stories today was a release or on albums that were released in the last seven days.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: A week can be a long time, when every day seems to shift the direction of your entire country. Egypt has had a week of demonstrations, counter demonstrations, and violence. The demonstrations are for and against the country's president, Mohammed Morsi.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And OK, quick review-- Morsi was democratically elected a couple months ago. But at the end of November, he shocked many Egyptians by issuing a decree giving himself enormous powers, basically putting all his decisions, past and present, above the law. He said he had to do this because judges appointed by Egypt's ousted dictator, Hosni Mubarak, were undermining him. Some of those judges had dissolved Egypt's newly elected parliament right before Morsi took office.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So now, if you follow the news at all, you've seen this-- both sides are dug in, each convinced that they represent true democracy in Egypt. There are a lot of ways for things to get worse, very few for them to get better. Nancy Updike reports on what has happened and how some of the anger is being spread around.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: Up until this past Wednesday, opponents and supporters of President Morsi had held their rallies in different places-- on purpose, to avoid confrontations. But late in the day on Wednesday, supporters of President Morsi, members of the Muslim Brotherhood, marched to the presidential palace, where some anti-Morsi protesters were camped out. And after that, all night long, people fought or ran or hid.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: By Thursday morning, seven people were dead, and hundreds were injured. And four of Morsi's advisers had resigned in protest. As of right now, Friday evening, around 6:00 PM Egypt time, the leaders of both sides aren't talking to each other, and protesters are still in the streets, separate and peaceful for the moment.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: When I was in Cairo after Mubarak was ousted last year, I saw a scene that now seems impossible-- writers and editors, secular Egyptians, who were talking over croissants with members of a formerly violent Islamist group named Gamaa Islamiya, an ally of the Muslim Brotherhood. The secular men and the devout men weren't becoming friends. But they weren't beating each other up in the streets, either.

speaker: yusuf al-qaid
utterance: Hello?

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: On Thursday night, I made a phone call through an interpreter. She was shouting a bit to make herself heard. And we called one of the people from that meeting, an Egyptian novelist in his 70s named Yusuf al-Qaid to find out his take on the week's events. He remembered me, but he wanted to make absolutely sure I knew where he stands in this fight.

speaker: translator
utterance: I would like our American journalist here to understand that I am not in any neutral position here. I am with a civilian modern state. I am against a religious state. I am against any rule based on religion.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: So against Morsi. And since he brought up the fact that I'm American, I told al-Qaid that I'd seen pictures of anti-Morsi protesters, people like him, carrying signs talking about the US and President Obama. I didn't mention this specific one to him, but I saw a sign that said, "Obama, your bitch is our dictator." The vehemence of al-Qaid's response caught me by surprise.

speaker: translator
utterance: In my view, the biggest betrayal that has taken place against the Egyptian people is the absolute support that the American administration has given to the Muslim Brotherhood. America is ignoring the violence that is conducted against the Egyptian people. America is completely silent and has voiced that its relationship with Egypt is strategic. And therefore, passing events do not affect this strategic relationship.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: By strategic relationship, he means that the United States is more concerned about Egypt's dealings with Israel than about Egypt's dealings with its own citizens. This week, more than ever, I realized that no matter how angry and caught up in their own national issues a person is, depending on what country they're in, they probably still have plenty of anger left over for the United States.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: After I hung up with al-Qaid, I called another person I met in Cairo last year-- completely different guy, a religious man, young, 28 years old, named Mohammed Agiba. Mohammed spent years in the Muslim Brotherhood. But now he's marching against Morsi too. He knew Morsi's power grab would divide the country. And he thinks the proposed constitution is a disaster that has to be stopped.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: And talking about the constitution is when we ended up at the same place I ended up with al-Qaid, the secular guy. Mohammed talked about how the constitution calls for a joint civilian military council, weighted toward the military, that has to be consulted before the president can declare a war. The council also has a role in deciding on the military's budget. Mohammed sees the council as one thing only.

speaker: translator
utterance: This is what the US wants; this is what Israel wants-- a regime which appears to be democratic to the people, but actually it is this defense national council which will be doing all the work. This council, the National Defense Council, will be the one ruling the country.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: So are you saying you think President Morsi or part of his government or all of his government are puppets of the United States?

speaker: translator
utterance: For sure President Morsi wants the interests of Egypt. However, he sees the implementation of this interest, or finding the interest, from a very narrow perspective that the United States has set for him. We do not want him to see that perspective through the United States' perspective.

speaker: translator
utterance: We want him to see it through the Egyptian people's vision and through the Egyptian people's perspective. And we say, please, the Egyptian people should be your priority and not the American administration.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: I asked Mohammed one more question, not about America, but about Egypt and the choices people have faced there since the revolution. I asked him if he'd voted for Morsi. He did, like a lot of people who are now protesting against Morsi.

speaker: nancy updike
utterance: He said he doesn't regret it. The alternative was worse. He says he just hopes Morsi can pull out of this and pull Egypt out too.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Nancy Updike. She's one of the producers of our show.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: OK, let's go back to America. Friday morning, Boston, Logan Airport, 5:40 AM.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: Delta. United.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: 30 times a night, six nights a week, Fred Beaton drives the shuttle bus on the same loop, from the parking garage to the terminals, picking people up, dropping them off, every 20 minutes, same loop. He's been doing this for 16 years, till this morning. He's retiring.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: Hopefully, this is my last trip around the airport.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: vinny
utterance: Freddie B, you'll never be done here, never.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: That one was his boss, Vinny, over the radio.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: Off to the sunset.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: But everybody got in on it.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: man on radio
utterance: Freddie B's last ride. [EVIL LAUGH].

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ryan murdoch
utterance: So do you feel sad at all, nostalgic, maybe?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: No, I don't feel sad. No.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ryan murdoch
utterance: Not even a little bit?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: I'm glad, happy. It's somebody else's turn.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: His stepson, Ryan Murdoch, is riding with him, making this recording and talking to him. They calculate that he's done this loop 128,000 times in 16 years. And at 6 o'clock, when he gets to the end of his very last ride, the guy who was supposed to show up was late.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So he has to do one more. Perfect, right? And then he gets to pull the shuttle bus over one last, last time, and climb out.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: All right. Hey, glory Hallelujah. I'll see you.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ryan murdoch
utterance: All right, we're done.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: We're done.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ryan murdoch
utterance: You've got a huge smile on your face.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: fred beaton
utterance: Good. Getting out of here, you know?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: In Chicago, Linc Cohen began his retirement this week. He worked at a steel mill for 18 years, and then for 20 years after, for the union AFSCME. Monday was his first day home as a retired person. And his wife, Sandi Wisenberg, had some questions. She recorded them.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: sandi wisenberg
utterance: Are you going to make the bed? You can make the bed now.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: linc cohen
utterance: Well, you got up after me today.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: sandi wisenberg
utterance: But I never make it.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: linc cohen
utterance: I know. When I get up last-- the day before, I got up after you, and I made it.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: sandi wisenberg
utterance: Right. But what if I get up last, and then you're still here. You can go up and make it.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: linc cohen
utterance: Yeah, I might. I might not.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: sandi wisenberg
utterance: Oh, I thought you don't like it when it's not made.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: linc cohen
utterance: I don't like it when it's not made. But I also don't like cleaning up your messes. I have enough of that to do.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: In other news with people not getting to work in the morning-- Springfield, Oregon, Monday morning of this week, 7:30, a grad student named Morgan Peach hears the alarm that is supposed to wake him up. Then he shuts it off. This happens again at 7:35--

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: --and then again at 7:40.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Once more at 7:45.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: You get the idea. 8:15, 8:25. Finally, 9 o'clock, his girlfriend Angela Evancie, who made this recording, steps in.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: It's time?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: angela jane evancie
utterance: It's time.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: It's time.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: He doesn't get up. It's finals week. Besides an exam, he has two research papers to turn in and 55 exams and papers to grade. Angela sees him struggle every day with waking up. But she thought, this week, this week, for once, he would do it when the alarm sounds, because he has so much to do.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Tuesday, it goes off first at 7:30, then seven more times-- 7:40, 7:45, 8 o'clock, 8:05, 8:10, 8:15, 8:20. Wednesday, pretty much the same deal. At some point, Angela says to her sleeping boyfriend--

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: angela jane evancie
utterance: Did you set the alarm for 9 o'clock?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: Yes, I did.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: angela jane evancie
utterance: Can you afford to sleep in that late?

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: I certainly can. I'm wealthy in time, not in money.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Wednesday night, Morgan tells Angela that the next morning, Thursday, he actually is going to have to get up early. A geography paper is due at noon.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: Yeah, could you set the alarm for 7:30 tomorrow? I'd like to get up at 7:30 and work on my research papers and finish them.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Hours pass.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: angela jane evancie
utterance: And now it's 8:00. The alarm went off, and he reset it for 8:30. I really thought he was going to do it this morning.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Sometime near 10:00 AM, they finally have this conversation.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: angela jane evancie
utterance: It's time to get up.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And then, still lying in bed, he explains the whole thing perfectly. It would be impossible to say this better.

act_title: Act Six: Boston, Logan Airport; Chicago, IL; Springfield, OR
speaker: morgan peach
utterance: It's almost as if the sleeping is that much sweeter when you have to get up or you think you have to get up, and then you don't.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Well, our program was produced this week by Sarah Koenig, our senior producer, Julie Snyder, and me, with Alex Blumberg, Ben Calhoun, Jonathan Menjivar, Lisa Pollak, Brian Reed, Robin Semien, Alissa Shipp, and Nancy Updike. Production help from Tarek Fouda. Amy Phillips, from Pitchfork Media, was our music consultant, finding brand new songs. Seth Lind is our operations director. Elise Bergerson's our administrative assistant.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: At our website this week, we have a gallery of photos taken on Instagram by people all over the world in these last seven days of events large and small. Emily Condon on our staff did the photo curating. She did so good. You should look. That's at our website, thisamericanlife.org.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This American Life is distributed by Public Radio International. And our film Sleepwalk With Me is now available for download at iTunes-- itunes.com/sleepwalkwithme. WBEZ management oversight for our program by our boss, Mr. Torey Malatia, who never stops saying--

speaker: hyder akbar
utterance: F This American Life. What the hell are you going to do with This American Life when you're dead?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: I'm Ira Glass. Back next week with more stories of This American Life.

speaker: announcer
utterance: PRI, Public Radio International.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: OK, everybody. Ready? Ready? Lights, camera, Christmas.

ep-482.speaker: pirecua
ep-482.utterance: Well, my parents say that I can't have a dog.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: This is Pirecua, age 11.

ep-482.speaker: pirecua
ep-482.utterance: So I wanted another animal that is, like, fuzzy, and it walks around.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: You know, I'm not really a pet sort of person. I think she knew she couldn't get a dog, basically.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: This is Linda, her mom. Linda is a reporter here at WBEZ, the station that our program comes from.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: So a guinea pig was, I think, something she felt she could actually ask for. You know, that's the second place, I guess. It's still fuzzy and walks around.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Linda's husband is Mexican. And the kids lived in Mexico when they were smaller. So they don't write to Santa to ask for what they want. The Mexican tradition at Christmas is to write to the three kings.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: So she wrote this letter to the three kings. And-- do you want me to read it?

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Yeah, yeah. Could you read it?

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: All right. It says, [SPEAKING SPANISH]. She says, like, dear three kings, I hope you're doing very well. I hope you're well.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: I thought that was a nice touch.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: That is a nice touch.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Yeah.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: [SPEAKING SPANISH]. She says, this year, I was thinking of asking for a guinea pig. And then she writes-- she has, like, an arrow. It's like an afterthought. She wrote, a real one. [SPANISH]. Then she goes on and asks for some other things. But what she really wanted-- I mean, has this whole list of things. But honestly, I don't ever remember her talking about anything else except the guinea pig.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: So, comes the big morning. This was two years ago. Pirecua was just nine. The three kings did, in fact, bring her a guinea pig. And, of course, she was thrilled. She named it Luna.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: The guinea pig was in her arms, and it was running around her bed. And she was just in love. Well, that lasted about an hour before I just noticed she was scratching her forearms a lot.

ep-482.speaker: pirecua
ep-482.utterance: And she said that they were, like, hives. I was allergic to my guinea pig.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: She was completely scared that I would give the guinea pig away immediately. And I think her one goal was to keep the guinea pig. So she definitely did not complain about the hives.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: They were big red blotches, the size of silver dollars. Pirecua, however, would not be deterred.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: She still held it. She tried for a while. I was like, maybe if you cover yourself up. So what she started doing was she would put on this full face mask that she usually used on the coldest days in Chicago.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: It was black. All you could see were her eyes. Linda showed me a photo of the full get up. You can see it on our website.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: She basically looks like a Zapatista rebel. She's got a long sleeve shirt. She's got her winter gloves on. And in the winter gloves, there's the little guinea pig peeking out from her hands.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Meanwhile, paper towels stick out several inches from the gloves.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: So that there's absolutely no gap between her long-sleeve shirt and the gloves.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: She looks like a young terrorist.

ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: With a cute guinea pig.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: With a cute guinea pig. Exactly. It looks like she's taken the guinea pig hostage or something.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Pirecua is devoted to Luna, still. Lets it run around her room. Makes sure it's fed. ep-482.speaker: linda lutton
ep-482.utterance: But it just feels a little weird, because she can't pick it up or hold it or even really pet it. So it's kind of like all the reasons you'd want a guinea pig, she can't have those.

ep-482.speaker: ira glass
ep-482.utterance: Today on our radio program, in these last few frantic preparatory days before the holiday, we have stories of parents and others trying to make the holiday incredible for the people that they love, Going to great and ridiculous lengths involving live animals, a deer, a sled, ancient reindeer bones, which lead only sometimes to the most magical Christmases.
